If you uncheck 'Automatically mark messages as read' in Settings/General/Reading & Display, messages remain marked as unread even if you open (read) them. They can be marked as read by pressing M.

Even though this would apply to all accounts, marking as read with M is not a great inconvenience. Otherwise, create a separate profile for the one account with that setting.

content:
I suppose you're still running TB 140.7.1esr now?

Gmail uses OAuth authentication. That means you'll have to allow cookies in Thunderbird for the authentication to succeed.

Are you using a VPN? If so, turn it off for the authentication.

Are you running a local web server, or any other service which may occupy TCP port 80 on your computer? If so, turn it off for the authentication.

The application /snap/upnp-server was listening on port 80 locallyvia the lighthttpd damon. Once I terminated that application Thunderbird was able to complete authentication.

content:
I'm not clear what your intention is. Are you trying to do a virgin install, as if Thunderbird was never on this computer? And there is nothing from a previous installation that you want to preserve, like old email and accounts? If so, look in the location where the user profiles are stored, which is, by default,

C:\Users\<your user name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird

Rename the Thunderbird folder to something like "Thunderbird.OLD" and try installing Thunderbird again. When you first run it after installing, it should create a fresh new profile for you and prompt you to create new accounts. Once everything is working the way you want, you can go back and delete the "Thunderbird.OLD" folder.

If this isn't what you're trying to do, please clarify and provide more details.

content:
The folder index and message list may have somehow gotten out of sync or the index is damaged. If so, easy fix:

- The first thing to try is to compact the folder (right-click on the folder name and choose "Compact".

- If that doesn't fix the problem, go on to the next possible fix, which is to Repair the folder. This is safe, but you might find that some messages you deleted earlier now re-appear. Right-click on the folder name, Properties, General Information, and click the "Repair Folder" button.

content:
dpauker said
View folders is "unified folders" with a unified inbox, and each account (except the gmail account) has a separate inbox as a sub folder.

Unified Folders is important info and probably it will be easy to get your Gmail inbox back in unified folders view. • R-click on the unified Inbox folder at the top and select "Properties" in the context menu; this will open a new window called "Edit Saved Search Properties for Inbox" (see image) • click on the button "Choose" to open another window called "Select Folder(s)" which displays a list of all accounts with all folders.. • search for your missing Gmail Inbox, set a check mark, click OK and then on the Update button Now you should see your Gmail Inbox displayed in the Unified Folder view

content:
We might be able to offer you more helpful advice if you could specify what you are trying to accomplish, or what problem you are trying to solve. I understand that it could be annoying or concerning to have an extra account ID# listed in the "back end" but it could be that it is not actually going to cause any problems, whereas, I would worry that it could potentially cause a problem to try to make any changes in the "back end" "Config Editor" AKA "Advanced Preferences".

Under the "Account Settings" for a given account, if I change the "Email Address" for that account, for example, if I change example@gmail.com to example@gmail.commeow, then I do find that this change is immediately reflected in the "useremail" list in the "Config Editor" AKA "Advanced Preferences". (Using two different proper names for the same user interface device -- brilliant as always, Mozilla)

So to reiterate, via the so-called front-end "Account Settings" for the account in question, you could temporarily change the e-mail address of the account, and see if that change then propagates to only one of the "duplicate" entries in the "useremail" list.

Even if you are able to determine that only one of the ID#s is correlated with your gmail account, I would still recommend against deleting anything in the "Config Editor" AKA "Advanced Preferences" that is associated with the other ID# that is not correlated. If you do make any such changes, I would recommend first backing up your entire mail folder, and, I would recommend being sure that you have a viable recovery process whereby you are able to recover from your backup, if needed. However, I would also recommend against messing around with backup copies of your mail folder, as this can get incredibly messy and confusing, and could potentially damage both mail folders, i.e. while testing out a recovery procedure you could end up downloading new e-mails to the backup copy of the mail folder, so then the original copy of the mail folder is missing those new e-mails... So I guess, any testing of backup and recovery procedures should be performed with mail folders and mail accounts that are used only for test purposes, such testing should not be performed with production folders and accounts...

creator: inspiredmac1

content:
Thanks for the clarification. Sorry, I should have assumed you were correctly creating a new folder in the first place. In looking at this again, I think the most likely reason you can't create a new folder will be that Thunderbird is unable to log into your e-mail account. For example, perhaps your username or password is not entered correctly in the Thunderbird settings. Further explanation follows:

It would help narrow down the problem if you can check if this problem is limited to creating new folders in your e-mail account, or if you are also unable to create new folders in your "local folders."

In the Thunderbird "folder tree" in which you are presented with your various folders, (Inbox, Drafts, Sent, etc) you should have an entry named "Local Folders" and also an entry whose name is your e-mail account address. These entries represent the "root level", respectively, of your local folders and your e-mail account folders.

If you right-click on the "Local Folders" root entry then you should be able to create a new folder within the "Local Folders," and likewise, right-clicking on the e-mail account root entry should allow you to create a new folder within the e-mail account.

If you are not able to create a new folder within "Local Folders", then perhaps your computer has run out of disk space, or, perhaps there is some other weird problem happening with your Thunderbird installation.

If you ARE able to create a new folder within "Local Folders", but you are NOT able to create a new folder within your e-mail account, then perhaps your e-mail account has run out of storage space, or perhaps your e-mail account is simply configured to deny you permission to create a new folder, or, perhaps there is a configuration problem whereby your e-mail account login settings (POP or IMAP settings, port numbers, username/password, etc) are not all set correctly per the instructions published by your e-mail account provider.
creator: antifascist

content:
It took me a while to understand you are not talking about spam at all. You are asking about filters in general. They are completely different things and to be honest I feel any attempt to manually menage spam with filters is destined to complete failure but will consume inordinate amounts of time.

Each mail account maintains a msgfiltersrules.dat file within it account folders in your profile With careful editing these text files can be bulk updated using a basic text editor (not a word processor) The first criteria is Thunderbird must not be running in any way when you are meddling in the profile folder. Bad things hempen if it is. The second thing is make plenty of backups because as I said careful editing, that means there is lots that can go wrong. But if you change one and save it and copy the change in a find and replace you should get the outcome you seek. But remember find and replace will replace every instance it sees of that text string. SO backup so you can recover if it does not work how you expect.

A full profile backup might be germane, as messing up filters can mess up stored mail in a folder you apply it against.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Please reference the attached screen image. In my attached screen image, if you point your mouse pointer directly at the horizontal line separating the list of messages from the "message preview pane", (this specific point is indicated on the attached screen image with a red circle located between the two red arrows) then your mouse pointer should transform from a normal pointer arrow into a double arrow. While your mouse pointer is a double arrow, you can then click and drag up or down, thereby enlarging or shrinking the size of the preview pane. If you drag all the way down, then the preview pane will be entirely removed, but can be restored by pointing at the same line and dragging upwards.

If you have a relatively small screen, or if your display resolution is set to be relatively small (smaller resolution results in everything being drawn larger on the screen) then you may find that use of the preview pane is not practical, as you may need to use all available space for simply navigating through the list of messages. In this case, you may find it to be more useful to view a message in a new tab or new window rather than viewing the message in the preview pane.

To view a message in a new tab or window, in the list of messages, simply click on the message entry once so as to highlight that particular message entry, and then press the "enter" key on the keyboard. Alternatively, right-click on a given message entry which will pop up a contextual menu from which you may elect to "open message in new tab" or "open message in new window."

If you do open messages in new tabs, you should take care to close each tab when done, otherwise, you will end up with multiple tabs open all at once, which can be confusing, and can make it difficult to find your main "All Folders" folder tree from which you select your inbox, sent, trash, etc, as after all, the main folder tree itself also occupies a tab. When too many tabs are open at the same time, it becomes difficult to find a particular tab.

As mentioned above, when you press the keyboard's "enter" key after highlight a given messages in the list of messages, that message will then be displayed in a new tab, or conversely, in a new window. If you have a preference for a new tab or a new window, you may configure that preference in the "Reading & Display" sub-section of the "General" section of the Thunderbird settings.

I hope this helps!
creator: antifascist

I have no idea what a .PING attachment is. Neither does the registered list of media types. https://www.iana.org/assignments/media-types/media-types.xhtml So I guess there is your answer.

For transmission by email media must be correctly identified. They Windows practice of using file extensions does not play in the internet realm where media types rule. Incorrect classification is a leading cause of attachments not opening upon receipt and opening once they are saved to disk. The sending application has misidentified to media type tag on the attachment.

Your last image looks like a HTML email that is being viewed in plain text. Check the view menu setting for Message Body As is set to original HTML.

content:
you saw a thread about this topic. But chose not to share what you had already been made aware of through that thread. So do not complain when you have exactly the same introductory information shoved your way, or someone assume you know a lot more than you do and start assuming you know how things work when you do not.

How sub folders are downloaded depends a lot on the server implementation of IMAP. This is especially true of those using the Microsoft version and the google version, neither of which actually work as anything more than some sort of emulation of IMAP with special quirks for each implementation. I seem to recall something about Bugs in Exchange meaning only top level IMAP folder get synced or the top two levels for exchange/office360/ Hotmail etc. Google actually have server side settings for IMAP that can get in the way when you want full copie0 have you checked those if relevant? Then there is the Yahoo implementation that just stops working when the number of mails in the account exceeds 10,000. I suggest you offer explicit details of the provider, how long you have had the account in Thunderbird, the number of other accounts you have, how frequently you have Thunderbird checking mail for each account. Some folk invite disaster by setting this to one or two minutes and then seek support because it takes so long to complete it never actually does before it starts again.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Do you have encrypt if possible selected in settings?
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Thanks, this is a good suggestion, however, I checked, and "Automatically enable encryption when possible" was already disabled.

Out of curiosity, just now I went ahead and enabled "Automatically enable encryption when possible" which then allowed me to also enable "Automatically disable encryption when recipients change and encryption is no longer possible." In theory this might help disable the encryption, because after all, encryption to the recipient in this case is not possible because Thunderbird does not have a PGP key for this recipient. However, no joy, upon testing with these new settings, Thunderbird is still encrypting the message, somehow.

Also, it should be noted, although the message is encrypted, it can't be decrypted, presumably because there was no valid key against which to encrypted it in the first place. Clicking the "Decrypt" button has no effect on the displayed message.
creator: antifascist

content:
antifascist said

In the Template that I am using, the "encrypt" button is not selected </blockquote>

I'm sorry, I must correct my original description here. It turns out that I was confused by Mozilla's awful user interface design which misled me into believing that opening the template would actually open the template, but instead it turns out that opening the template actually opens a portal to some alternate dimension in which opening the template actually instantiates a new e-mail object from the template...

It turns out that when I choose the menu option for "Edit Template" I then discover that the template has the "Encrypt" button selected, and the "Encrypt" button can not be deselected. Well, it can be deselected, but saving the template unfortunately does not save the deselected state of the "Encrypt" button.  :-(

So, it's a bug that doesn't seem like it will have any workaround.  :-( I did however file a bug report so there is a chance it might get fixed eventually https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=2015226
creator: antifascist

content:
update: I tried to manually create and send a new e-mail from my template, just to see what would happen, and what happened is that the new e-mail was created and sent without encryption, which is the expected behavior for an e-mail recipient who does not have any PGP key associated with it.

However, as reported above, when my message filter uses the "Reply with Template" action, then the new e-mail is always sent with encryption, even when the recipient has no PGP key, and so the new e-mail is therefore unreadable.
creator: antifascist

content: update: turns out that every Template is always saved in an encrypted state, even when the user deselects the "Encrypt" button.
creator: antifascist

content: I found a workaround, as follows: Create and save your Template inside a mail account that does not use encryption, and then drag and drop your Template from the Templates folder of your mail account that does not use encryption into the Templates folder of your mail account that does use encryption. This will allow for the correct functioning of the "Reply with Template" function of the Message Filter Filter Rules, in other words, the "Reply with Template" function will send unencrypted reply messages to recipients who do not employ encryption. If at any point in time you need to edit your Template, you would need to first drag and drop the Template over to a mail account that does not use encryption, perform and save the edits, and then drag it back to the encryption-using mail account in which the Template is actually used.
creator: antifascist

content: well nevermind, it turns out that the above workaround doesn't work after all
creator: antifascist

content:
Matt said
Do you have encrypt if possible selected in settings?

So guess what... it turns out that Thunderbird has a setting for this in two entirely different locations... In the Thunderbird "Privacy and Security" settings, there is this setting...

"Automatically enable encryption when possible"

Meanwhile, in the "Account Settings", there is this setting...

"Disable encryption for new messages" "Enable encryption for new messages"

It turns out that the Disable/Enable "Account Settings" completely override the "enable" "Privacy and Security" settings...

Apparently the "Automatically enable encryption when possible" setting is there just to confuse the user, because this setting apparently doesn't actually do anything.

Have I mentioned that I love Mozilla products?
creator: antifascist

content: Hmm I was wondering what does it mean in the user interface when it says "Use hardware acceleration when available" It see that for me it is checked should I uncheck it?
creator: antifascist

content:
antifascist said
Hmm I was wondering what does it mean in the user interface when it says "Use hardware acceleration when available" It see that for me it is checked should I uncheck it?

It is a rather esoteric setting and really has no correct settings. The correct value depends a lot of the video driver installed on the system and the capability of the video card installed on that device. Generally you turn it off if things get blurry or render in an odd manner but otherwise on makes video and some other functions happen faster. I lost the argument for it to be defaulted to off some 10 years ago. The argument is they (firefox) don't test the off default only the on one and as it is a Firefox feature Thunderbird developers really do nothing except set the initial default value.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Problema risolto grazie alle indicazioni ricevute dal supporto del team Infomaniak. Non era un problema di Mozilla Thunderbird, si trattava di applicare le istruzioni contenute in questa pagina della KB della piattaforma https://faq.infomaniak.com/711

Il recente cambio della psw dell'account influiva direttamente solo per l'accesso alla web suite ed all'app per smartphone (Infomaniak mail). Per l'accesso alla mailbox da mailreader locale via IMAP\POP\SMTP è stato necessario generare e creare una password specifica e separata, conosciuta come "device password".

Credo che l'informazione potrebbe essere utile ad altri utenti Infomaniak che come me amano Mozilla Thunderbird.

===============

Problem solved due to the answer by Infomaniak support team. Was not a problem of Mozilla Thunderbird. Need only to apply the instruction at this support page: https://faq.infomaniak.com/711

The account password recently changed only regarding the login to Infomaniak web suite and tools (Android app).

To correctly login into mailbox via mailreader from IMAP/POP/SMTP services it needed to generate and create a specific password, known as a “device password.”

Hope that those informations can be useful to others Infomaniak users that love Mozilla Thunderbird, like me.
creator: Parnassius21

content:
These steps assume you use windows:

here is the info in brief steps:

  1. ensure thunderbird is NOT running on old machine
  2. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  3. this should open windows file explorer in Appdata\roaming folder
  4. highlight the Thunderbird folder and copy to external media
  5. ensure thunderbird is installed on second computer, started once and NOT running
  6. enter %appdata% in search window on task bar and press Enter key
  7. you should be in Appdata\roaming folder , copy&paste the exported Thunderbird folder there. This WILL prompt to overwrite an existing folder of same name. allow it 
#   start thunderbird and all should be there

content:
Ok, to restore the menu bar for composing, do this: - click 'new message' button - next, click alt key to display menu bar - now, click view>toolbars and tick 'composition toolbar

Where you mislead me, was in your example of 'reply, forward, etc' as they are NOT on the menu bar.

For screenshots, if you use windows, there is a nice, simple, free, utility at https://www.reasyze.com/
